ToolTip.Text: Use a high-heat cooking oil, such as Canola oil, olive oil or peanut oil
Preheating means to heat up an oven, grill, or similar appliance before cooking something.

Most ovens will have a dial with numbers between 1 and 9. In that case, medium heat would be 5 on the knob. Generally, you want to choose the middle number. Every oven is different however, so pay attention - If your food consistently cooks too quickly, reduce the knob. If it consistently cooks too slow, increase the knob.

Dip a paper towel into the cooking oil without saturating it. You want to coat the grate, but do not want the oil dripping. Make sure to use an oven mitt and tongs to run the paper towl over the grate!
Basting means to coat the grilling chicken with the sauce again. This keeps the meat from drying out and adds flavour. You should use a basting brush to keep your hands away from the heat.

RecipeStep.StepText: Preheat the grill for medium heat.
RecipeStep.Title: Preheat Grill

RecipeStep.StepText: In a shallow bowl, mix 1/3 cup mustard, 1/4 cup honey, 2 tbsp. mayonnaise, and 1 tsp. steak sauce. Set aside a small amount of the honey mustard sauce for basting (See next step), and dip all 4 chicken breast halves into the remaining sauce to coat.
RecipeStep.Title: Make Sauce & Coat Chicken

RecipeStep.Warning: Make sure not to get too close to the heated grill! Use an oven mitt and tongs when oiling the grill.
RecipeStep.StepText: Lightly oil the grill grate. Grill chicken over indirect heat for 18 to 20 minutes, turning occasionally, or until juices run clear. Baste occasionally with the reserved sauce during the last 10 minutes. Watch carefully to prevent burning!
RecipeStep.Title: Oil Grill, Grill Chicken
